details.package_name: Potential SQL injection via string-based query concatenation

aikido_score_reasons.llm_summary: Authentication SQL query directly concatenates user-provided credentials without sanitization, enabling SQL injection and authentication bypass.
aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: AI assessed finding as easily exploitable
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: Aikido's AI assessment upgraded the severity of this finding because it looks easily exploitable.

issues.description: SQL injection might be possible in these locations, especially if the strings being concatenated are controlled via user input.
issues.title: Potential SQL injection via string-based query concatenation
issues.remediation: If possible, rebuild the query to use prepared statements or an ORM. If that is not possible, make sure the user input is verified or sanitized. As an added layer of protection, we also recommend installing a WAF that blocks SQL injection attacks.

scw_info.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')
scw_info.description: The software constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

aikido_score_reasons.llm_summary: SQL injection vulnerability in getUserInfo allows authentication bypass and data extraction due to unsanitized username parameter in query.
aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: AI assessed finding as easily exploitable
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: Aikido's AI assessment upgraded the severity of this finding because it looks easily exploitable.

issues.description: SQL injection might be possible in these locations, especially if the strings being concatenated are controlled via user input.
issues.title: Potential SQL injection via string-based query concatenation
issues.remediation: If possible, rebuild the query to use prepared statements or an ORM. If that is not possible, make sure the user input is verified or sanitized. As an added layer of protection, we also recommend installing a WAF that blocks SQL injection attacks.

scw_info.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')
scw_info.description: The software constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

aikido_score_reasons.llm_summary: SQL injection vulnerability allows direct user input into query through login parameter, with no sanitization or validation present.
aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: AI assessed finding as easily exploitable
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: Aikido's AI assessment upgraded the severity of this finding because it looks easily exploitable.

details.package_name: Rendering unescaped input can lead to XSS attacks

issues.description: Outputting user input risks cross-site scripting vulnerability. This could in turn be used to facilitate account takeover attacks.
issues.snippet: "HostName": "<%=request.getParameter("HostName")%>",
issues.title: Rendering unescaped input can lead to XSS attacks
issues.remediation: Sanitize unsafe data using escapeXml().

aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: Not a sensitive string
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: This string is likely part of UI definitions and not sensitive.

issues.description: Identified a generic password field
issues.author: apvk

ignore_reasons.title: Not a sensitive string

details.package_name: HttpServletResponse output can be used for XSS attacks

aikido_score_reasons.llm_summary: The servlet outputs unescaped user input from the txtEmail parameter directly into an HTML response, enabling cross-site scripting attacks.
aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: AI assessed finding as likely exploitable
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: Aikido's AI assessment slightly upgraded the severity of this finding because it looks exploitable.

issues.description: Cross-site scripting detected in HttpServletResponse writer. User input was detected going directly from the HttpServletRequest into output.
issues.snippet: response.getWriter().write(content);
issues.title: HttpServletResponse output can be used for XSS attacks
issues.remediation: Ensure your data is properly encoded using org.owasp.encoder.Encode.forHtml: 'Encode.forHtml( <variable> )'

details.package_name: Stacktrace might be exposed to end user

issues.description: Handling exceptions only with a printStackTrace() might result in stacktraces and variables being exposed in log files. Moreover, the developers who might need these stacktraces to detect the problems might never find them in those logs.
issues.snippet: e.printStackTrace();
issues.title: Stacktrace might be exposed to end user
issues.remediation: Log the errors to a special-purpose error tracking system, such as Sentry.

scw_info.name: Active Debug Code
scw_info.description: The application is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active, which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information.

issues.description: Handling exceptions only with a printStackTrace() might result in stacktraces and variables being exposed in log files. Moreover, the developers who might need these stacktraces to detect the problems might never find them in those logs.
issues.snippet: ex.printStackTrace();
issues.title: Stacktrace might be exposed to end user
issues.remediation: Log the errors to a special-purpose error tracking system, such as Sentry.

details.package_name: 3rd party Github Actions should be pinned

issues.description: A third-party GitHub Action was imported, and is not pinned via a hash. This leaves your CI/CD at risk for potential supply chain attacks, if the affected GitHub Action is compromised.
issues.snippet: uses: jitsecurity-controls/jit-github-action@latest
issues.title: 3rd party Github Actions should be pinned
issues.remediation:
When using 3rd party Actions in your GitHub Workflow, it is a best practice to pin the version by including the commit hash. You can retrieve the commit hash from the releases tab of the affected GitHub's Action repository. For example:

 The commit hash for https://github.com/actions/setup-node/releases/v4.1.0 is 39370e3970a6d050c480ffad4ff0ed4d3fdee5af. When pinning, the Action's definition would be: - uses: actions/setup-node@39370e3970a6d050c480ffad4ff0ed4d3fdee5af.

details.package_name: JSP Scriptlets are used and are hard to keep secure

aikido_score_reasons.llm_summary: The code directly outputs an unencoded request parameter in a JSON-like context, allowing for XSS through the HostName parameter.
aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: AI assessed finding as easily exploitable
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: Aikido's AI assessment upgraded the severity of this finding because it looks easily exploitable.

issues.description: Scriptlets are difficult to use securely and are considered bad practice.
issues.snippet: "HostName": "<%=request.getParameter("HostName")%>",
issues.title: JSP Scriptlets are used and are hard to keep secure
issues.remediation: Instead, consider migrating to JSF or using the Expression Language '${...}' with the escapeXml function in your JSP files.

aikido_score_reasons.llm_summary: The provided JSP snippet is safe as it contains only static comments and no dynamic or user-controlled content.
aikido_score_reasons.rule_title: AI assessed finding as false positive
aikido_score_reasons.rule_info: Aikido's AI assessment ignored this finding because it seems to be a false positive.

issues.description: Scriptlets are difficult to use securely and are considered bad practice.

ignore_reasons.title: AI assessed finding as false positive
